Award.AwardTitle: CIF: Small: Collaborative Research: New Approaches to the Design of Joint Source-Channel Codes

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
Joint source-channel coding and decoding techniques are rapidly emerging as important design tools for the complexity- and latency-constrained transmission systems that underlie the multimedia revolution. In such scenarios these techniques have the potential to offer the same performance with less complexity or delay compared with systems which completely separate the source and channel coding functions. The investigators develop theoretical insights and practical approaches into the construction of joint source-channel codes by addressing certain classes of optimal variable-length error correcting codes and their application to networks. The insights gained by these studies facilitates new advanced coding strategies as well as a fundamental theory that guides the design of future wireless and multimedia systems.

One approach to joint source-channel coding is to consider prefix condition codes which have an inherent source compression property and are in addition able to detect or correct errors resulting from noise on the communication channel. Thus, these codes typically require a smaller amount of redundancy than classical channel codes to achieve the same amount of error resilience. However, the current understanding of these codes remains rather limited which has led researchers to focus on heuristics. The investigators address these issues by tackling research problems in three interrelated directions. In particular, we (1) develop new minimum-redundancy variable-length codes with inherent error resilience properties and investigate issues related to their design and compression performance; (2) study the application of this family of codes to sensor and ad hoc networks and gain insight into their repercussions for higher communication layers; (3) investigate the construction of reversible variable-length codes including those with special error-correcting properties.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Joint source-channel coding and decoding techniques are rapidly emerging as important design tools for complexity- and latency-constrained transmission systems that underlie the multimedia revolution. In such scenarios these techniques have the potential to offer the same performance with less complexity or delay compared to systems which completely separate the source and channel coding functions. The proposal has significantly enhanced the state-of-the-art knowledge in joint source and channel coding by employing ideas from information theory, coding theory, the analysis of algorithms, and computer networking.

One of the results obtained in this study is the design of a provably optimal lossless joint source-channel coding algorithm which is able to detect errors on the communication channel almost for free, i.e., without sacrificing the compression performance. In a typically used retransmission-based scheme this construction has a throughput advantage of 37% compared to a separate scheme based on an entropy code and a cyclic redundancy check for error detection. In this project we have also investigated advances to the lossy source coding case, where the reconstruction of the source is performed according to some fidelity constraint. For example, we have derived an extremely low-latency lossy compression scheme based on spatially coupled low-density generator matrix codes, which in contrast to other approaches can provide an instantaneous output and therefore is well suited for streaming applications or applications with deadline constraints. We have also leveraged the connection of lossy source compression and privacy and derived optimal practical privacy mappings based on polar codes. Here, the compressed (encoded) version of the original data minimizes the privacy leakage with respect to a specific subset of the data. In another activity of this project, we addressed a long standing problem and investigated the shape of the probability distribution of the compressed symbols for distributed lossy source compression. We obtained the surprising result that unlike lossless compression, a random seed is not required to make the encoder output nearly uniform. This result has the potential to better exploit the available communication resources in secure communication problems, where uniformly distributed random keys are required for security. In summary, the project has significantly advanced the theory of joint source-channel coding and has the potential to impact the operation of practical wireless systems in the future.

Further, this project helped to provide training and professional development to Ph.D. students and a postdoctoral researcher at New Mexico State University and the New Jersey Institute of Technology, respectively. By integrating some of these research problems and their solutions into the curriculum of the PI’s information theory and coding graduate classes, the project also enabled exposing students in these classes to state-of-the-art research questions. The results of this project have been disseminated via publications in journals and presentation at international conferences within the information theory and coding community.
